What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course if you have already taken a course on 20th century history or politics. If you don't know a lot about that time period, taking this class will probably just confuse you until you get to a point in the semester when suddenly everything starts to make sense.

A history of the Cold War with a focus on Europe - Germany's central role, how European powers, especially Britain and France, influenced the Soviets/Americans, economic policy, trends like Eurocommunism and counterculture, affect of 3rd world on European developments.I would definitely recommend this class. You learn a lot through the readings and especially through the seminar style discussions, something you would not get if you took Gaddis' Cold War class.Also, Maragkou was great.Decent amount of work - one presentation, one test, and final paper with about 150 pages of reading per week.
I would recommend this seminar to anyone who wants to broaden their knowledge of how the cold war impacted europe and how europe shaped the cold war.
